answerText: neutrinos[10] From 1978 to 1989, Lederman was director of this research facility and home of the Tevatron, the second highest-energy accelerator after the LHC. Bison roam the grounds of this Batavia, Illinois site.
heading: ACF Regionals  |2015 | Illinois A + Ottawa A  | 2 | Science | Physics | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Answer the following about Leon Lederman, an American physicist who won the Wolf Prize, for 10 points each. [10] Lederman, together with Melvin Schwartz and Jack Steinberger, won the Nobel Prize in 1988 for the discovery of the muon variety of these particles. These nearly massless leptons are named for their lack of electric charge.
